title: Ticket #395: EventLog.lock fd leak and submission events are bogus
description:
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=496432

All the gory details are in the BZ above. The general issue is when the EVENT_LOG is configured in the condor_schedd, the schedd leaks fds to the event log's lock file whenever a cluster is submitted. The result is the schedd runs out of fds and EXCEPTs.

The workaround for this is to not use the EVENT_LOG.

2009-Apr-25 17:35:47 by matt:
Attached are two strace logs, one with the EVENT_LOG on NFS and the other not...

The NFS log shows FDs 11,13,14,15 being leaked.

It appears that the lock is opened as fd 11, then the log is opened as fd 12. The header is written to fd 12. Then for each job in the cluster I submitted, queue 5, the lock is reopened though it exists, and that new fd is leaked. Finally at the end of the submission the last lock fd is closed, 16, and the fd to the log, 12, is closed.

In the non-NFS case, the trace looks pretty similar, except the opens on the lock file fail, and thus can't be leaked.

It seems the qmgmt.cpp::CloseConnection doesn't properly clean up the UserLog usr_log. It initializes it multiple times, and each initialization would leak the fd.

This raises another question, do the events get written if a job is submitted via SOAP?

2009-Apr-27 07:52:03 by matt:
With my last commit, c2cfbff08, I think this is resolved. The issue was qmgmt.cpp's CloseConnection would call UserLog::initialize for each proc in the submitted cluster. It did so purely (or so it seemed) to change the cluster/proc id held by the UserLog. However, because of a change back in May '08, the initialize call would also initialize lock fds. The result of init+init+init... meant that only the last init's fds were cleaned up when the UserLog was deleted. The fix I implemented for this was to init the UserLog once and then call setGlobalCluster/Proc to set the cluster/proc.

The reason this did not leak on a local fs was because opening the lock file was failing with EACCESS, and the lock fd was never recorded on the UserLog. This is kinda scary because it means the lock wasn't really acquired and yet writing to the log went ahead. On NFS the open succeeded and subsequent inits would overwrite it.

A separate issue here is why the open was failing on a local fs and if locking is happening properly on NFS, but that's another ticket that should be filed - likely by Nick.
derived_tickets: #451   Event Log writer leaks when re-initialized
attachments:
• el.strace 5742 bytes added by matt on 2009-Apr-25 22:36:34 UTC.
    strace with EVENT_LOG on NFS
  • el.nonnfs.strace 6866 bytes added by matt on 2009-Apr-25 22:36:56 UTC.
    strace with EVENT_LOG not on NFS
check_ins:
2009-Apr-26 19:32   Check-in [14554]: Resolved bug introduced in previous quick fix for #395 Avoid intializing the UserLog with uninit variables, just use bogus 0s to start. Then use setGlobalCluster/Proc instead of re-initializing for each submit event. (By Matthew Farrellee )
2009-Apr-25 23:14   Check-in [14553]: Quick fix for fd leak when EVENT_LOG is on NFS, possibly incomplete (#395) This fix only prevents the UserLog from being initialized multiple times, causing an FD leak. It does not handle failure of the initialization, which was also not handled by the previous code. (By Matthew Farrellee )
2009-Apr-21 16:57   Check-in [14529]: Fixed handling of EVENT_LOG_ROTATION_LOCK parameter (#395) (By Nick LeRoy )
2009-Apr-21 09:41   Check-in [14526]: Log writer: don't instantiate a FileLock when we fail to create the lock file (#395) (By Nick LeRoy )
2009-Apr-20 16:15   Check-in [14519]: Fixed a bug in the event log writer in which it will try to close a -1 fd if it fails to open the rotation lock file. (#395) (By Nick LeRoy )
2009-Apr-20 15:37   Check-in [14516]: Fixed a bug in which the log writer was free()ing memory instead of delete. (gittrac #395) (By Nick LeRoy )
creator: matt
